questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with a history of multiple sclerosis and recurrent urinary tract infections comes to the emergency department because of flank pain and fever. Her temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F). Examination shows left-sided costovertebral angle tenderness. She is admitted to the hospital and started on intravenous vancomycin. Three days later, her symptoms have not improved. Urine culture shows growth of Enterococcus faecalis. Which of the following best describes the most likely mechanism of antibiotic resistance in this patient?

choices.text: Increased efflux across bacterial cell membranes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Production of beta-lactamases confers resistance to penicillins, cephalosporins, and rarely carbapenems, for example, in E. coli that produce extended-spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL). Vancomycin is not a beta-lactam antibiotic, meaning that the production of beta-lactamases would not confer resistance to the drug.

B) INCORRECT:

Alteration of penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) decreases the binding affinity of beta-lactams. This is the mechanism of resistance found in methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Vancomycin, however, is not a beta-lactam and does not bind PBPs. Alteration of PBPs is therefore not a mechanism that would lead to resistance against vancomycin.

C) INCORRECT:

The increased production of antibiotics efflux pumps across the bacterial cell membrane confers resistance to tetracyclines and fluoroquinolones and is shown by some Staphylococcus and Pseudomonas strains. It is not a mechanism that would lead to resistance against vancomycin.

D) CORRECT:

Vancomycin binds to the d-alanine-d-alanine terminus of peptidoglycan precursors, thereby inhibiting cell wall synthesis of gram-positive bacteria (e.g., Enterococci). Acquisition of van genes (e.g., through transposition of plasmid-encoded genes) can result in a change from the d-alanine-d-alanine sequence to a different amino acid sequence, such as d-alanine-d-lactate (vanA and vanB genes), which inhibits binding of vancomycin to peptidoglycan.

E) INCORRECT:

Enterococci develop resistance to macrolides via methylation of the 23S rRNA-binding site for the drug. Because vancomycin does not interact with the ribosome, however, this cannot be the mechanism of resistance at work in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has pyelonephritis caused by vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE). Enterococci can transfer antibiotic resistance to other bacteria via transposition of plasmid-encoded van genes.

questions.text: An 82-year-old man with alcohol use disorder is brought to the emergency department from his assisted living facility because of fever and cough for 1 week. The cough is productive of thick, mucoid, blood-tinged sputum. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F) and respirations are 20/min. Physical examination shows coarse inspiratory crackles over the right lung field. Sputum cultures grow gram-negative, encapsulated bacilli that are resistant to amoxicillin, ceftriaxone, and aztreonam. Which of the following infection control measures is most appropriate for preventing transmission of this organism to other patients in the hospital?

choices.text: Require all staff and visitors to wear droplet masks
Transfer patient to a positive pressure room
Require autoclave sterilization of all medical instruments
Isolate patient to a single-occupancy room
Transfer patient to a negative pressure room

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Droplet precautions are used for highly contagious diseases that are transmitted through particles of respiratory secretions. These include Neisseria meningitidis, influenza, Bordetella pertussis, and others. ESBL-producing bacteria are not transmitted through droplets and therefore droplet precautions are not indicated in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Positive pressure rooms can be used for immunocompromised patients. They have a ventilation system that creates positive pressure in the room, allowing air to flow out of and preventing air from being drawn into the room. This is not indicated in this patient as he is not immunocompromised, and it would not help reduce transmission of ESBL-producing bacteria.

C) INCORRECT:

Autoclave sterilization of all medical instruments is used in prion diseases, such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, as well as in spore-forming bacteria or fungi. It is not necessary to prevent transmission of ESBL-producing bacteria.

D) CORRECT:

Multidrug-resistant strains of bacteria, such as ESBL-producing strains, are a greater public health hazard than infections with organisms of a normal resistance spectrum, and thus need stricter infection control measures. In addition to the standard contact precautions and strict hand hygiene, patients should be isolated in single-occupancy rooms.

E) INCORRECT:

Negative pressure rooms are used for highly contagious airborne diseases (e.g., tuberculosis, measles, varicella, smallpox). They have a ventilation system that creates negative pressure in the room, allowing air to flow into and preventing air from flowing out of the room. Moving the patient to a negative pressure room is not necessary to prevent transmission of ESBL-producing bacteria.
questions.hint: Fever, productive cough, and localized crackles are suggestive of pneumonia. The patient's currant jelly sputum, residency in an assisted living facility, alcohol use disorder, and findings of gram-negative, encapsulated bacilli make healthcare-associated Klebsiella pneumonia a likely diagnosis. Sputum cultures show multi-drug resistance, raising suspicion for an extended-spectrum beta-lactamase-producing (ESBL) strain of this bacteria.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man undergoes open reduction and internal fixation of a left femur fracture sustained after a motor vehicle collision. Three days after the surgery, he develops fever and redness around the surgical site. His temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F). Physical examination shows purulent discharge from the wound with erythema of the surrounding skin. Wound culture of the purulent discharge shows gram-positive cocci in clusters. Treatment with oral dicloxacillin is initiated. Four days later, the patient continues to have high-grade fever, pain, and purulent discharge. Which of the following characteristics of the infecting organism best explains the failure to improve with antibiotic therapy?

choices.text: Presence of an impenetrable outer membrane

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pyrogenic toxins are proteins that cause damage to the plasma membranes of capillaries and produce rashes. Some strains of S.aureus can produce TSST-1 pyrogenic superantigens, which cause toxic shock syndrome. However, pyrogenic toxins do not produce methicillin resistance in Staphylococci.

B) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics must penetrate the outer membrane of gram-negative bacteria to exert their antimicrobial effects (e.g., on intracellular targets or the inner cytoplasmic membrane). Most gram-negative bacteria are resistant to vancomycin through mutations of integral outer membrane proteins such as porins. Staphylococci, being gram-positive, have both a cytoplasmic membrane and a cell wall but not an outer membrane.

C) INCORRECT:

Beta-lactamases are bacterial enzymes that have the ability to neutralize the core structure of the beta-lactam antibiotics. Although methicillin is a narrow-spectrum beta-lactam antibiotic, methicillin resistance (e.g., in MRSA) is not achieved through beta-lactamase activity.

D) INCORRECT:

Bacterial efflux pumps are a family of integral proteins that remove toxic substances and antibiotics from cells and grant them resistance to a wide range of drugs, for example, tetracycline. Methicillin resistance, however, has evolved through a different method.

E) CORRECT:

Penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) are enzymes that cross-link peptidoglycans during cell wall synthesis. They are targets of antibiotics with a beta-lactam functional group, which bind irreversibly to the enzyme's active site. MRSA expresses PBPs that do not interact with methicillin or other beta-lactams, allowing resistance and requiring treatment with vancomycin or linezolid.
questions.hint: This patient has a surgical-site infection (SSI) acquired during his hospital stay. The gram stain findings in this patient suggest infection by Staphylococcus aureus, which is the predominant organism causing SSIs. Lack of response to penicillin drugs in staphylococcal infection indicates methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA).

questions.text: Three days after surgical repair of a distal right radius fracture due to a severe motor vehicle collision, a 62-year-old man is admitted to the ICU with severe wound pain and fever. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F). Physical examination shows erythema and edema of the right arm that extends up to the elbow. Yellow pus drains from the surgical wound. Cultures from the pus grow gram-positive bacteria in grape-like clusters that are resistant to nafcillin. Which of the following measures is most effective for decolonization of the causal pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alcohol-based oral rinses are not used for MRSA decolonization; the oral cavity is not a significant reservoir for this organism.

B) INCORRECT:

Permethrin hair wash is not used for MRSA decolonization. The scalp is not a significant reservoir for this organism, and permethrin lacks activity against S. aureus. Permethrin is used to treat head lice infestation and scabies.

C) INCORRECT:

Nebulized colistin is not used for MRSA decolonization. Aerosolized medications do not effectively reach common sites of MRSA colonization. Moreover, colistin is not effective against gram-positive bacteria. Nebulized colistin is used to treat P. aeruginosa infections that are resistant to other antibiotics, particularly in patients with cystic fibrosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral vancomycin is not used for MRSA decolonization; the gastrointestinal tract is not a reservoir for this organism. In addition, oral vancomycin is not systemically absorbed (minimal bioavailability). Intravenous vancomycin can be used to treat MRSA bloodstream infections. Oral vancomycin is used to treat C. difficile infection.

E) CORRECT:

Mupirocin ointment applied to the nares is the treatment of choice for MRSA decolonization, which is performed in certain high-risk settings (e.g., in the ICU, preoperatively). The anterior nares are the most common site of MRSA colonization; other sites include the hands, axillae, and perineum. In addition to intranasal mupirocin therapy, regular cleaning with chlorhexidine solution is also recommended.
questions.hint: Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive bacterium that grows in grape-like clusters and often causes nosocomial wound infections. Resistance to nafcillin indicates the growth of methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA).

questions.text:
A 78-year-old nursing home resident is hospitalized with a fever and cough that have not improved despite empiric treatment with levofloxacin.
On examination, he has a temperature of 38.6 °C, a blood pressure of 90/48 mm Hg, a heart rate of 120 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. He appears ill and has egophony over the right lower lobe.
On laboratory testing, he has a leukocyte count of 22,000 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000). Sputum and blood cultures are reported to have grown a levofloxacin-resistant Klebsiella oxytoca that was flagged as producing an extended-spectrum beta-lactamase.
Which one of the following antibiotic regimens is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clinical failure of third-generation cephalosporins in severe infections with ESBL-producing pathogens has been well documented, even if these agents are reported as sensitive; therefore, ceftriaxone and ceftazidime should not be used.

B) INCORRECT:

Fluoroquinolones should not be used for empiric therapy of serious infections from ESBL-producing organisms, because the plasmids encoding for ESBL genes frequently also carry genes conferring resistance to this class of agents.

C) INCORRECT:

When susceptibilities of an ESBL-producing organism are known, the use of two active agents is generally not warranted; thus, a combination, such as ceftazidime plus amikacin, provides no clear benefit and increases the risk of adverse effects.

D) INCORRECT:

Clinical failure of third-generation cephalosporins in severe infections with ESBL-producing pathogens has been well documented, even if these agents are reported as sensitive; therefore, ceftriaxone and ceftazidime should not be used.

E) CORRECT:

This nursing-home resident is hospitalized with pneumonia. Treatment can be challenging, but isolating the pathogen can help narrow the therapeutic options. Carbapenems (including meropenem) are considered the first-line agents for an infection caused by extended-spectrum beta-lactamase-producing (ESBL-producing) organisms.

Key learning point: The optimal treatment for a serious infection caused by an extended-spectrum beta-lactamase-producing pathogen is a carbapenem.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man with end-stage kidney disease requiring hemodialysis is hospitalized after reporting 2 weeks of intermittent fevers and shaking chills that occurred after his dialysis sessions. When he initially presented to the emergency department, he had a temperature of 38.3°C, but the rest of his examination was unremarkable. Two sets of blood cultures were obtained, and he was started empirically on intravenous vancomycin and gentamicin. Within 12 hours, both sets of blood cultures were growing gram-positive cocci in clusters.
On hospital day 2, the patient has an abrupt decline in mental status and requires insertion of an endotracheal tube and mechanical ventilation. CT of the head reveals multiple widely distributed cerebral infarctions. The patient is transferred to the intensive care unit, where a transthoracic echocardiogram reveals a 0.6-cm x 0.5-cm mobile vegetation on his mitral valve.
After 24 hours, the organism recovered from the initial blood cultures is identified as methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). The patient is continued on vancomycin.
Which one of the following strategies is most appropriate for minimizing the in-hospital spread of this patient’s MRSA infection?

choices.text: Screening cultures and targeted MRSA decolonization of the patient’s health care providers
Addition of rifampin to the patient's current antibiotic regimen to enhance intracellular killing of MRSA
Treatment of all of the patient’s close contacts with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for 10 days
No additional interventions beyond the antibiotic therapy the patient is already receiving
Routine hand hygiene with alcohol-based hand rub and initiation of contact precautions

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Health care providers may become transiently or permanently colonized with MRSA in the course of caring for patients with MRSA infection. However, the role of routine screening cultures and targeted decolonization of health care providers who care for patients with MRSA has not been definitively established. This approach may be considered as part of an investigation of an outbreak of nosocomial MRSA infections.

B) INCORRECT:

Rifampin is often used as an adjunctive agent in patients with MRSA infections of prosthetic devices or certain deep-seated infections (e.g., central nervous system infections) because of its ability to penetrate biofilms and achieve high intracellular concentrations. Its effect on MRSA colonization and transmission has not been evaluated.

C) INCORRECT:

Household contacts of patients with MRSA infection are more likely to be colonized with MRSA. However, empiric treatment of these contacts with systemic antibiotics (e.g., trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) should not be part of a strategy to reduce hospital transmission of MRSA. This approach may needlessly expose asymptomatic individuals to the adverse effects of antibiotics and also promote the development of antibiotic-resistant strains of MRSA. Decolonization of close contacts with topical regimens (chlorhexidine solution and mupirocin ointment) may be a reasonable strategy for reducing the risk of recurrent MRSA infections among individual patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Providing appropriate systemic antibiotic therapy to a patient with MRSA infection does not obviate the need for contact precautions, because systemic antibiotic therapy may not necessarily eliminate the risk for MRSA transmission. Moreover, objects in the patient’s environment are often contaminated with MRSA and can be vectors for transmission.

E) CORRECT:

Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) causes a wide spectrum of health care-associated and community-acquired infections. Prevention of MRSA infections, including the transmission of MRSA from patient to patient in acute care settings, is a critical component of all infection-control programs.

In 2014, the Society of Healthcare Epidemiology of America (SHEA) and the Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) jointly updated the practice guidelines for preventing MRSA transmission and infection in acute care hospitals. Among the basic practices recommended for all acute care hospitals is the use of contact precautions for patients with documented MRSA infection or colonization. This recommendation is based on several studies showing that contact precautions can reduce the spread of MRSA, particularly when coupled with active surveillance. Contact precautions include:

• Placing patients with known MRSA infection or colonization in single or private rooms
• Requiring health care personnel to don a gown and gloves upon entering the patient’s room
• Performing routine hand hygiene, preferably with an alcohol-based rub, upon entering and exiting the patient’s room

Key learning point: The most appropriate interventions to prevent the in-hospital spread of a patient’s documented infection with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus are routine hand hygiene with an alcohol-based hand rub and initiation of contact precautions.
